data.title: Invalid SubTexture created using another SubTexture as parent
data.body:
In my app I create a TextureAtlas using a texture obtained from another atlas, as described here: http://forum.starling-framework.org/topic/putting-one-textureatlas-inside-another-textureatlas. Now, when I create another Texture using this inner atlas, such Texture's frame is not set right, which in effect makes it render not the way it should.

As far as I can tell, this problem is due to SubTexture constructor not checking if its parent texture is also a SubTexture which can be rotated or trimmed.

data.title: Add a mute property to MovieClip?
data.body:
I'm suggesting only a more generic mute property (defaulting to false) to avoid playing any sound when transitioning to a new frame (either in advanceTime or when doing a direct call to set currentFrame).

My specific use case is that I wanted to be able to scrub backwards or manually jump directly to a specific frame outside the normal advanceTime animation, and wanted to have  sound only play during the natural animation of increasing frames within advanceTime.

While I could have suggested more access to specific private variables or a setCurrentFrame with an optional disable sound, I thought maybe just being able to toggle sound while jumping to a specific frame like:

mov.mute = true;
mov.currentFrame = 4; (if it has a sound it won't play)
mov.mute = false;

works for me, and maybe there are more general use cases where a mute flag would help too...

data.title: Get item rotation from Atlas
Touch events still live after flash.events.Event.DEACTIVATE / ACTIVATE on iOS
data.body:
I'm developing a game that has a view with zoom/pinch with 2 fingers feature.
During the game, it shows a native AdMob fullscreen at each X minutes.

The ANE I'm using (I developed it too) makes the NativeApplication object to dispatch an _Event.DEACTIVATE_ when the banner will show, and dispatches _Event.ACTIVATE_ when the ad has been closed.

The Starling's **TouchProcessor** class listens to these events and calls _onInterruption()_ internally, which aborts the current touches, setting the touches in the _mCurrentTouches_ vector to the phase _TouchPhase.ENDED_.

The problem is when an user is zooming/pinching very fast and the fullscreen banner pops up. After the banner is closed and Starling is started again, sometimes, on iOS only, the touches that were on screen are still alive, and only are dismissed in the next deactivate event.

I solved this problem changing the _onInterruption()_ method, cleaning the _mQueue_ vector after _mCurrentTouches_, as in the original code:

```
mCurrentTouches.length = 0;
mQueue.length = 0;
```

data.title: Multiple flattened Sprites are not batched (rendered on separate drawTriangle() calls).
data.body:
I have a Sprite (let's call it Main Sprite) which contains other Sprites (Inner Sprites) containing Images. All Images use the same texture, alpha value, blend mode, etc. and can be batched. What I do is call flatten() on each Inner Sprite, so all Images added to each Inner Sprite are rendered together. But what I expected to see is all Inner Sprites also being batched and rendered on a single drawTriangles() call, but instead every Inner Sprites renders on a separate call. Now, I'm not sure if this should works this way or is it faster/slower this way, but just would like to know if there's some kind of reasoning behind this approach.

PS. I know that if I added all Images to a single Sprite and flatten() this Sprite I'd get a single drawTriangles() call in effect, but I cannot do that for other reasons.

data.title: Looping Tween lead to a stack overflow if on hold for too long
data.body:
If advanceTime is called with a large number 
and the tween is a looping tween
and the period of the tween is short

the last statement in Tween.as/advanceTime will lead to a recursive call:

if (carryOverTime) 
   advanceTime(carryOverTime);

carryOverTime is reduced in each call by the period of the tween but still this can lead to a very deep recursion, eventually crashing the flashplayer. (after some 256 recursions or so)

A rare case but still one that is hard to find.

This should be handled by possibly skipping some of the cycles and using % operator on carryOverTime instead of decreasing it linearly.

data.title: Transformation Matrix Setter erroneous for 90 rotation
Image.width and Image.pivotX issue
data.body:
I think I found an issue with image.width and image.pivotX

My game uses two different textures sizes.  One for the ipad and one for the iphone.  ipad size is 2 times the iphone size.

To use the same code for both of these textures, I simply resize them in the code to the iphone size.  Then I let starling handle the image display via mipmaps.

So the code looked like this:

image.width  = 34;  // half the size of the iPad textures
image.pivotX = image.width;  // trying to get the pivot on the right side of the image

The end result was that it would pivot in the middle of the image.  So essentially it was using image.pivotX = image.width / 2;   

When I did image.pivotX = 68;   It then worked correctly.

data.title: Areas for reducing temporary object creation in Starling BitmapFont related functions
data.body:
Given this recent topic where a Scout profile is shown for an 'idle' app, but more specifically when BitmapFont text is shown on screen (the Starling showStats text in this case):
http://forum.starling-framework.org/topic/memory-usage-increasing-at-constant-rate-200kb10seconds

If you focus in on the screenshot on the expanded area related to BitmapFont, and particularly frequent changing BitmapFont text (like timers or stats text as in Starling showStats).

I think it hilights a few areas of improvements that could reduce temp object creation internal to Starling even further.

The one simple specific suggestion would be to add a:
Texture.getFrame(resultRectangle=null):Rectangle
function along with/used instead of the current texture.frame property that forces a new Rectangle instance on every call.

As you can see in the Scout profile, BitmapFont needs to call texture.frame on every update of text because of the image.readjustSize call, so with an added Texture.getFrame(resultRectangle=null), Starling could use this with a static HELPER Rectangle in three places in Starling source code:
Image constructor 
Image readjustSize
BitmapFont parseFontXml

The second area for improvement is all the objects that are temporarily created in BitmapFont.arrangeChars
this obviously gets called every time the text changes.
There are minor things like reusing a static instance for
`lines = new Vector.<Vector.<CharLocation>>();`
instead of creating a new one each time and in the while loop, setting its length = 0 would work.

Also, I think a more fundamental caching of the `Vector.<CharLocation>`, as well as new `<CharLocation>[]` could be made, since arrangeCharacters is a private function, and given that the length of certain text strings are multiple and small, one could imagine reusing `Vector.<CharLocation>` and CharLocation instances in an internal pool (possibly setting a max pool size of like 20-30 so most smaller text strings just reuse instances but if someone asked for an extremely large text string it would just create and throw away new CharLocation instances as it does now)

I realize this optimization is more complicated and only useful in BitmapFont environments, but I think BitmapFont use in mobile environments is the preferred technique to reduce memory use, so I think the BitmapFont code could also benefit from super-optimized low temporary object creation too.

Thanks
